The Skylon concept dates back to about 1984 - so OVER 30 years. It was originally a British Aerospace project called HOTOL. When BAe pulled out, it was rebadged as Skylon.


Regarding the takeover of Orbital ATK by Northrop Grumman - the one reservation I would have is that it is yet another removal of "commercial competition" from the system - which I don't think is ever a good thing. Don't forget, Northrop, Grumman, Mortion, Thiokol, Orbital Sciences etc were all once separate corporations all competing for business - sometimes against each other. Now they are one giant conglomerate.

ARCA says that their SSTO concept saves money because it reduces complexity. The idea is that they don't need an upper stage engine or decoupling mechanism, thus making the rocket easier to produce quickly and cheaply in spite of the payload hit compared to a two-stage rocket.

Now, I don't know how true any of this is, but it's what they use as their justification for making it an SSTO rocket.

Hi Tim. Around the 5:00 minute mark you put the blame on the supplier for the part that failed on the SpaceX CRS-7 mission. But NASA's Independent Review Team's published report (March 12th, 2018) has a different, somewhat more nuanced take on it. It seems to me that this is the relevant quote from that report:

“It is important to note that the IRT’s conclusions regarding the direct, and immediate causes are consistent with the determination made by the SpaceX AIT investigation findings. Where the IRT differs with SpaceX is in regards to the initiating cause. SpaceX in their AIT report identifies “material defect” as the “most probable” cause for the rod end breaking. However, the IRT’s view is that while “rod end breakage due to material defect” is credible, the IRT does not denote it a “most probable” since the IRT also views “rod end manufacturing damage”, “rod end strut mis-installation”, “rod end collateral damage” or some other part of the axial strut breaking as equally credible causes to have liberated the COPV. Lastly, the key technical finding by the IRT with regard to this failure was that it was due to a design error: SpaceX chose to use an industrial grade (as opposed to aerospace grade) 17-4 PH SS (precipitation-hardening stainless steel) cast part (the “Rod End”) in a critical load path under cryogenic conditions and strenuous flight environments. The implementation was done without adequate screening or testing of the industrial grade part, without regard to the manufacturer’s recommendations for a 4:1 factor of safety when using their industrial grade part in an application, and without proper modeling or adequate load testing of the part under predicted flight conditions. This design error is directly related to the Falcon 9 CRS-7 launch failure as a “credible” cause.”

If you could comment on this in some future video, that would be great. Thanks!

I only started to surf YouTube seriously this year, and have caught up on all of your shows. I am as huge a fan of SpaceX as you. When I was a kid in the early Space Age I watched Mercury and Gemini land with parachutes, but (a big reader) KNEW that iconic rockets were supposed to return and land tail first. Took a lot longer than I thought, but it's been so much fun to see Falcon 9s do it! (I do think the Electron electric approach is very smart and original for their scale.)
Thanks for all of the great info on everything. You've answered questions I had, and questions I didn't know to ask.
